label: Type 2 Diabetes
diet: Follow a balanced diet rich in vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats.
Limit sugar and refined carbohydrate intake.
Monitor portion sizes and carbohydrate servings.
lifestyle: Engage in regular physical activity (30-45 minutes most days).
Manage stress and get adequate sleep.
preventive: Attend regular check-ups and eye exams.

label: Type 1 Diabetes
diet: Carbohydrate counting and meal planning aligned with insulin dosage.
Include high-fiber foods and avoid skipping meals.
Limit sugary drinks and high-fat processed foods.
lifestyle: Exercise routinely and adjust insulin as needed.
Use continuous glucose monitoring if available.
preventive: Regular monitoring of blood glucose and HbA1c.
Foot care and annual screenings for complications.
Stay current with vaccinations (e.g., flu, pneumonia).

label: Hypoglycemia
diet: Eat frequent, small meals with balanced carbohydrates.
Avoid alcohol on an empty stomach.
Include snacks to prevent low blood sugar during or after exercise.
lifestyle: Monitor blood glucose before, during, and after activity.
Educate about symptoms of low blood sugar.
Carry glucose tablets or snacks at all times.
preventive: Review medication doses with healthcare provider.

label: Metabolic Syndrome
diet: Adopt a Mediterranean or DASH diet.
Increase fiber intake from fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.
Reduce saturated fat, trans fats, and added sugars.
lifestyle: Engage in aerobic and resistance exercise regularly.
Reduce sedentary time; quit smoking if applicable.
preventive: Regular screening for blood pressure, cholesterol, and glucose.
Early intervention for abnormal lab results.

label: Insulin Resistance / Hyperinsulinemia
diet: Focus on low-glycemic-index foods and whole grains.
Control calorie and carbohydrate intake.
Avoid sugary beverages and high-fat snacks.
lifestyle: Aim for gradual, sustained weight loss if overweight.
Manage stress and improve sleep patterns.
preventive: Periodic screening for diabetes and cardiovascular risk.
Educate about risk factors and early symptoms.

label: Hypertension
diet: Reduce salt intake to less than 2,300 mg per day.
Eat a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat dairy.
Limit alcohol consumption.
lifestyle: Engage in regular aerobic exercise (e.g., walking 30 minutes most days).
preventive: Schedule regular doctor visits for cardiovascular risk assessment.

label: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
diet: Limit protein intake as advised by a healthcare provider.
Reduce sodium and potassium in the diet if indicated.
Ensure adequate hydration.
lifestyle: Maintain blood pressure and blood sugar control.
preventive: Regular kidney function monitoring with labs and urine tests.
Manage associated conditions like hypertension and diabetes.

label: Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)
diet: Follow fluid restrictions if advised.
Limit intake of potassium and phosphorus foods.
Consume adequate calories to prevent malnutrition.
lifestyle: Monitor daily weight and urine output.
Seek prompt medical care for infections or symptoms.
preventive: Early detection and treatment of underlying causes.
Repeat kidney function monitoring until recovery.

label: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diet: Increase intake of iron-rich foods like lean meats, beans, and spinach.
Consume vitamin C-rich foods to enhance iron absorption.
Avoid tea or coffee with meals.
lifestyle: Manage heavy menstrual bleeding or other blood loss sources.
Monitor symptoms like fatigue and pallor.
preventive: Treat underlying causes of blood loss.

label: Megaloblastic Anemia (Folate/B12 deficiency)
diet: Increase dietary folate from leafy greens, fortified cereals.
Include vitamin B12 sources like meat, dairy, eggs.
Consider supplements if dietary intake is insufficient.
lifestyle: Address alcohol use or malabsorption issues.
Time medications to improve absorption if needed.
preventive: Prompt supplementation with folate and B12.

label: Hemolytic Anemia
diet: Maintain a balanced diet with adequate folate.
Stay hydrated to reduce hemolysis complications.
Avoid triggers like certain medications or toxins.
lifestyle: Avoid extreme temperatures or physical stressors.
preventive: Vaccination against encapsulated organisms if spleen removed.
Routine blood counts and hemolysis monitoring.

label: Thalassemia Trait/Disease
diet: Ensure adequate folate intake.
Avoid excess iron unless recommended.
Maintain balanced nutrition to support hematopoiesis.
lifestyle: Regular medical follow-up for monitoring anemia.
Avoid strenuous physical exertion if symptomatic.
preventive: Avoid iron overload with chelation therapy if necessary.
Routine specialist care including transfusion management.

label: Polycythemia / Erythrocytosis
diet: Maintain adequate hydration to prevent blood thickening.
Limit iron intake only if advised by a physician.

label: Heart Failure
diet: Limit sodium intake to reduce fluid retention.
Eat small, frequent meals with balanced nutrients.
Avoid caffeine and alcohol.
lifestyle: Engage in light to moderate physical activity as tolerated.
Weight monitoring daily for fluid retention.
preventive: Regular follow-up for symptom and fluid status.
Manage comorbidities like hypertension and diabetes.

label: Acute Myocardial Infarction (probable)
diet: Initiate a heart-healthy diet low in saturated fats and cholesterol.
Increase intake of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.
lifestyle: Gradual return to physical activity under supervision.
preventive: Immediate medical attention and adherence to treatment plan.
Medications to prevent clotting and manage risk factors.

label: Pulmonary Embolism / Deep Vein Thrombosis
diet: Maintain balanced diet; avoid sudden large changes in vitamin K rich foods if on anticoagulants.
Stay hydrated.
lifestyle: Encourage early mobilization and physical activity.
Avoid prolonged immobility during travel or hospitalization.
preventive: Avoid smoking and maintain healthy weight.

label: Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)
diet: Follow hospital-based diet as per acute illness.
Maintain adequate calorie and protein intake.
lifestyle: Strict bed rest during acute phase.
Monitor for bleeding or clotting complications closely.

label: Sepsis / Severe Bacterial Infection
diet: Provide supportive nutrition with adequate hydration.
Consider enteral or parenteral nutrition if indicated.
preventive: Early identification and treatment of infection source.
Follow vaccination guidelines to prevent infections.

label: Bacterial Infection (suggestive)
diet: Maintain hydration and balanced nutrition to support immune function.
lifestyle: Avoid spreading infection (hygiene and isolation if required).

label: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diet: Balanced diet rich in antioxidants and omega-3 fatty acids.
Limit saturated fat and processed foods.
Maintain adequate calcium and vitamin D intake.
lifestyle: Regular moderate exercise to maintain joint and heart health.
Avoid sun exposure or use sun protection due to photosensitivity.

label: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diet: Consume omega-3 rich foods like fish to reduce inflammation.
Include antioxidant-rich fruits and vegetables.
Limit processed foods and sugars.
lifestyle: Engage in low-impact exercises such as swimming or walking.

label: Complement Consumption / Immune Complex Disease
diet: Maintain well-balanced nutrition to support immune health.
Avoid foods that may trigger immune reactions.
lifestyle: Manage stress as it affects immune function.
preventive: Prompt treatment of infections or triggers.

label: Wilson's Disease
diet: Avoid copper-rich foods like shellfish, nuts, chocolate, mushrooms.
Maintain a balanced and nutritious diet.
lifestyle: Adhere to chelation therapy as prescribed.
Regular monitoring of liver and neurological status.

label: Copper Deficiency (e.g., Menkes, malabsorption)
diet: Increase copper rich foods such as meat, shellfish, nuts, seeds.
Consider supplementation under medical supervision.
preventive: Early diagnosis through clinical and lab evaluation.

label: Lead Poisoning
diet: Adequate calcium, iron, and vitamin C intake to reduce lead absorption.
Balanced diet to support detoxification.
lifestyle: Avoid exposure to lead sources (old paint, contaminated water).

label: Rhabdomyolysis
diet: Maintain hydration to flush myoglobin.
Balanced diet to support muscle recovery.
lifestyle: Avoid excessive physical exertion and trauma.
Seek timely treatment of muscle injuries.

label: Chronic Liver Disease / Cirrhosis (suggestive)
diet: Low sodium diet to prevent fluid retention.
Adequate protein intake unless contraindicated.
Avoid alcohol completely.
preventive: Manage comorbidities like diabetes and obesity.

label: Hypertriglyceridemia
diet: Reduce intake of refined carbohydrates and sugars.
Increase omega-3 intake from fish or supplements.
Limit alcohol consumption.
preventive: Control associated conditions such as diabetes.

label: Elevated LDL / Hypercholesterolemia
diet: Reduce saturated and trans fats.
Increase dietary fiber.
Include plant sterols and stanols.

label: Hypoalbuminemia (suggestive)
diet: Ensure adequate protein intake.
Consume nutrient-dense foods.
lifestyle: Address underlying causes such as liver or kidney disease.
preventive: Monitor serum albumin in at-risk patients.

label: Vitamin B6 Deficiency
diet: Increase intake of poultry, fish, potatoes, and fortified cereals.
Supplement under medical guidance if needed.

label: Folate Deficiency
diet: Consume leafy green vegetables, citrus fruits, beans, and fortified grains.
Supplementation as advised.
lifestyle: Address causes like alcohol use or malabsorption.
Routine prenatal care for women of childbearing age.

label: Hypercoagulable State / Thrombotic Disorder
diet: Maintain a balanced diet with adequate hydration.
Limit foods affecting blood clotting (e.g., Vitamin K rich foods if on anticoagulants).
lifestyle: Stay physically active but avoid prolonged immobility.
Avoid smoking and manage body weight.
preventive: Avoid trauma or situations increasing clot risk.

label: Nonspecific Inflammation / Acute Phase
diet: Eat anti-inflammatory foods rich in omega-3 fatty acids.
Maintain hydration and balanced nutrition.
lifestyle: Manage stress and get ample rest.
Follow medical advice to treat underlying cause.
preventive: Prompt treatment of infections or injuries.

label: Primary Hyperparathyroidism
diet: Ensure adequate hydration.
Limit calcium and vitamin D supplementation only as advised.
Avoid high phosphate foods.
lifestyle: Engage in weight-bearing exercises to strengthen bones.

label: Hypoparathyroidism
diet: Adequate calcium and vitamin D intake as prescribed.
Avoid high phosphate foods.
lifestyle: Regular exercise to maintain bone health.
Monitor for symptoms like muscle cramps.
preventive: Calcium and vitamin D blood monitoring.

label: Hyperkalemia
diet: Limit potassium-rich foods such as bananas, oranges, potatoes.
Avoid salt substitutes containing potassium.
lifestyle: Avoid medications that raise potassium without medical supervision.
Stay hydrated but follow fluid restrictions if any.
preventive: Manage underlying renal or endocrine conditions.

label: Hypokalemia
diet: Increase intake of potassium-rich foods.
Include fruits like bananas, oranges, and vegetables.
lifestyle: Avoid excessive use of diuretics unless prescribed.
Report symptoms such as muscle weakness promptly.
preventive: Monitor potassium regularly, especially with diuretics.
Treat underlying causes like diarrhea or vomiting.

label: Hypernatremia
diet: Maintain adequate free water intake.
Limit sodium intake if advised.
lifestyle: Avoid dehydration in elderly or ill patients.
preventive: Treat underlying conditions causing water loss.
Seek water balance management in hospital settings.

label: Hyponatremia
diet: Follow fluid restriction as prescribed.
Avoid hypotonic fluids if advised.
preventive: Address underlying causes like SIADH or diuretics.

label: Hepatic Encephalopathy
diet: Limit dietary protein intake per medical advice.
Include complex carbohydrates and small frequent meals.
lifestyle: Adhere to lactulose or rifaximin therapy.
preventive: Monitor ammonia and liver function regularly.
Manage precipitating factors like infections or GI bleeding.

label: Urea Cycle Disorder
diet: Restrict protein intake carefully.
Ensure adequate caloric intake from carbohydrates and fats.
lifestyle: Avoid catabolic states and prolonged fasting.
preventive: Early diagnosis and emergency care plans.

label: Nephrotic Syndrome
diet: Limit sodium to reduce edema.
Maintain adequate protein intake.
Monitor fluid intake as advised.
lifestyle: Avoid infections and promptly treat them.
Measure weight daily to assess fluid retention.
preventive: Regular urine protein and kidney function tests.

label: Syndrome of Inappropriate ADH Secretion
diet: Follow fluid restriction.
Maintain balanced nutrition while restricting fluids.

label: Diabetes Insipidus
diet: Maintain adequate hydration.
Limit caffeine and alcohol.
lifestyle: Adhere to prescribed desmopressin or other treatments.

label: Renal Tubular Acidosis
diet: Maintain a well-balanced diet including fruits and vegetables.
Alkali supplementation as prescribed.
lifestyle: Regular monitoring of growth in children.

label: Urinary Tract Infection (alkaline urine, e.g., Proteus)
diet: Drink plenty of fluids (at least 1.5 liters of water daily).
Consider cranberry supplements to help prevent bacterial adhesion.
Avoid bladder irritants like caffeine, alcohol, and acidic foods during infection.
lifestyle: Maintain good personal hygiene; wipe front to back after bathroom use.
Urinate frequently and empty bladder fully.
Urinate soon after sexual intercourse to flush bacteria.
preventive: Seek prompt treatment of infections with antibiotics as prescribed.
Undergo imaging if recurrent infections with alkaline urine to check for stones.
Avoid use of spermicides or diaphragms if prone to recurrent UTIs.

label: SjÃ¶grenâ€™s Syndrome
diet: Stay hydrated to combat dry mouth and eyes.
Eat moist, soft foods to ease oral discomfort.
Avoid alcohol and caffeine which worsen dryness.
lifestyle: Use saliva substitutes and regular dental care.
Protect eyes with artificial tears and sunglasses.
Manage fatigue with balanced rest and activity.
preventive: Regular rheumatology follow-up for systemic management.
Screen for associated complications like lymphoma.

label: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diet: Balanced diet rich in antioxidants, fruits, and vegetables.
Avoid processed foods and alcohol in excess.

label: Scleroderma
diet: Eat soft, high-fiber foods to ease swallowing difficulties.
Limit salt intake to manage hypertension.
Avoid foods that worsen reflux.
lifestyle: Protect skin and avoid cold exposure.
Regular gentle exercises to maintain joint mobility.
Manage GERD symptoms with lifestyle changes.
preventive: Routine pulmonary function and cardiac monitoring.
Adhere to prescribed treatment and therapy.

label: Dermatomyositis / Polymyositis
diet: Nutritious diet to support muscle health.
Adequate protein intake.
Avoid foods causing inflammation if identified.
lifestyle: Physical therapy to maintain muscle strength.
Manage fatigue with rest and pacing activities.
preventive: Monitor for respiratory and cardiac issues.

label: Hyperhomocysteinemia
diet: Increase folate, vitamin B6, and B12 rich foods.
Limit foods high in methionine if advised.
lifestyle: Regular exercise to improve cardiovascular health.

label: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diet: Consume animal products like meat, dairy, and eggs.
Consider B12 supplements if vegetarian or malabsorption present.
lifestyle: Manage underlying causes like pernicious anemia.

label: MTHFR Mutation Associated Disorder
diet: Increase intake of folate-rich foods and vitamins B6 and B12.
Avoid excessive folic acid supplements unless prescribed.
preventive: Regular homocysteine and related lab monitoring.

label: Insulinoma
diet: Frequent small meals to prevent hypoglycemia.
Include complex carbohydrates and protein.
lifestyle: Avoid fasting and strenuous exercise without glucose monitoring.

label: Factitious Hypoglycemia
diet: Regular balanced meals with controlled carbohydrates.
Avoid excessive sugar intake.
lifestyle: Close monitoring of blood glucose levels.

label: Severe Pneumonia
diet: Adequate hydration and calorie intake.
Balanced diet with protein for recovery.

label: Meningitis
diet: Maintain hydration and balanced nutrition.
Provide supportive care during illness.
lifestyle: Supportive care in hospital as needed.

label: Septic Shock
diet: Supportive nutrition tailored in ICU setting.
Maintain fluid balance.
preventive: Early recognition and treatment of sepsis.

label: Muscular Dystrophy
diet: Balanced diet supporting muscle health.
Adequate vitamin D and calcium.

label: Polycythemia Vera
diet: Maintain hydration.
Avoid iron supplements unless prescribed.
lifestyle: Avoid smoking and manage cardiovascular risk.
preventive: Monitor for complications such as thrombosis.

label: Secondary Polycythemia
diet: Hydration and balanced nutrition.
Avoid excess iron unless indicated.
lifestyle: Address underlying causes such as hypoxia.

label: Common Variable Immunodeficiency
diet: Maintain a balanced and nutritious diet with a variety of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean protein, and healthy fats.
Avoid highly processed foods and maintain adequate hydration.
lifestyle: Practice good hygiene including regular hand washing.
Engage in moderate exercise as tolerated.
Manage stress with meditation, yoga, or relaxation techniques.
Avoid smoking and limit alcohol intake.
preventive: Stay connected with healthcare providers for immunoglobulin therapy and infection management.
Avoid contact with people who are sick.

label: Selective IgA Deficiency
diet: Balanced diet supporting immune function.
Consider supplementation if other deficiencies present.
lifestyle: Good personal hygiene to reduce infection risk.

label: Multiple Myeloma / Monoclonal Gammopathy
diet: Maintain adequate protein and calorie intake.
Include calcium and vitamin D-rich foods for bone health.
lifestyle: Manage fatigue with balanced activity and rest.

label: Hereditary Angioedema
diet: Avoid known triggers including certain foods or alcohol.
Balanced nutrition to support overall health.

label: Polymyalgia Rheumatica
diet: Anti-inflammatory diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and omega-3 fatty acids.
Limit processed foods and sugars.
lifestyle: Light to moderate exercise to maintain mobility.
preventive: Adherence to corticosteroid therapy as prescribed.

label: Temporal Arteritis (Giant Cell Arteritis)
diet: Balanced diet with adequate calcium and vitamin D.
Limit sodium if on steroids.
lifestyle: Regular exercise within limits of physical ability.
Monitor for vision changes and report promptly.

label: Lymphoma
diet: Maintain balanced nutrition to support immune function.
Avoid foods that cause gastrointestinal discomfort.
lifestyle: Prevent infections with precautions like hand hygiene.

label: Leukemia
diet: Nutrient-rich and calorie-dense to support treatment.
Manage side effects like nausea with small, frequent meals.
lifestyle: Prevent infections with hygiene and avoiding sick contacts.

label: Testicular Cancer
diet: Balanced, nutrient-dense diet during treatment.
Adequate hydration.

label: Selective IgM Deficiency
diet: Balanced diet supporting immune health.
lifestyle: Good hygiene and infection prevention practices.

label: Hyper-IgM Syndrome
diet: Nutritional support including adequate calories and protein.
lifestyle: Avoid infection sources and maintain hygiene.

label: Urea Cycle Disorder (unspecified)
diet: Restrict protein intake as per medical advice.
Ensure adequate caloric intake from carbohydrates and fats.

label: Aceruloplasminemia
diet: Avoid excess copper and iron intake.
Maintain balanced nutrition.

label: Acute Phase / Inflammatory Condition
diet: Anti-inflammatory diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and omega-3 fatty acids.
Maintain hydration.
lifestyle: Manage stress and rest as needed.
Follow treatment plans for underlying cause.
preventive: Early identification and management of inflammation.

label: Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus
diet: Maintain adequate hydration.
Avoid excessive salt intake.

label: Dehydration / Volume Loss
diet: Replenish fluids and electrolytes promptly.
Consume balanced nutrition to support recovery.

label: Heart Failure (concentrated urine)
diet: Restrict sodium and fluid intake as advised.
Balanced diet for overall health.
lifestyle: Monitor daily weight and symptoms of fluid overload.
Engage in light physical activity as tolerated.

label: Hepatorenal Syndrome
diet: Limit sodium and fluid intake.
Adequate nutritional support.

label: Protein-losing Enteropathy / Malabsorption
diet: High-protein diet to compensate for losses.
Avoid irritant foods and allergens.
Supplement vitamins and minerals as needed.
